entry.title: Nobel Laureates & Humanitarians Call for Unconditional Release of Detained Armenians in Azerbaijan

media:group.media:title: Nobel Laureates & Humanitarians Call for Unconditional Release of Detained Armenians in Azerbaijan
media:group.media:description:
üìçArmenia signals readiness for closer relations with EU while meeting counterparts in Brussels. The number of EU observers on the Armenian border will increase by 50% from 138 to 209. üìçOver 150 global humanitarians, Nobel Peace laureates, and leaders have signed a letter issued today urging the unconditional release of ethnic Armenians illegally held in Azerbaijan. üìçInterview with Artyom Geghamyan, Director of Armenia‚Äôs International Chamber for Mining: https://youtu.be/eelYlHmpbLE

entry.title: Harnessing buried riches to bolster Armenian autonomy

media:group.media:title: Harnessing buried riches to bolster Armenian autonomy
media:group.media:description:
In this episode of the Civilnet podcast, host Patrick Elliott interviews Artyom Geghamyan, Director of Armenia‚Äôs International Chamber for Mining, about modernizing and diversifying the country's extractive sector. They discuss opportunities to harness Armenia's mineral wealth for economic and energy security while balancing environmental protection. Insights are shared on how strategic mining projects and sector reforms can attract critical foreign investment to further unleash Armenia's underground untapped potential.

entry.title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time to break free from an outdated education system,‚Äù Larisa Hovannisian

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time to break free from an outdated education system,‚Äù Larisa Hovannisian
media:group.media:description:
In this episode, we explore the life of Larisa Hovannisian, from her childhood and education in Yerevan, Moscow, Wisconsin, and Phoenix to her life as the founder and CEO of Teach for Armenia. We explore important topics such as her family roots, her journey in establishing Teach for Armenia, and the challenges and drives that helped her become a successful social entrepreneur. Finally, Larisa shares her view on the importance of faith, self-belief, life purpose, parenthood, social-emotional learning, and the role of education today.
About Larisa Hovannisian
Larisa Hovannisian is the founder and CEO of Teach for Armenia, a social impact organization dedicated to catalyzing impact-driven leaders addressing educational inequity for all children in Armenia and formerly in Artsakh. She holds a double degree in International Business and French, a minor in Graphic Design from St. Norbert College in De Pere, Wisconsin, and a master‚Äôs degree in special education from Arizona State University. As an educational activist, Larisa was nationally recognized by the Armenian government in 2016 for her contribution to the advancement of Armenia through her work with Teach for Armenia.
Program Overview Mindful Leaders dives into the stories of people who have achieved prominence, walked incredible journeys, and have defined culture.
Lara sits down with specialists, thinkers, and change catalysts to deconstruct insights, events, and lessons that have shaped their personal and professional lives and have enabled them to create meaning and connection.
00:00 Intro 1:06 Early childhood 4:23 Historical narratives of trauma 9:00 Leading through challenges; having purpose and faith 14:30 Parenthood, fulfillment and unlocking our talents 16:50 Social-emotional learning and the future of education with AI 24:15 Teach for Armenia and organizational culture 30:36 Grandparents Leonid Gurunts and Larisa Isahakyan; learning from our history 36:13 Conclusion and final reflections

entry.title: Artsakh parliament deputies issue a rare statement

media:group.media:title: Artsakh parliament deputies issue a rare statement
media:group.media:description:
üìçArtsakh National Assembly members issue a rare statement in Yerevan stressing their commitment to protecting the rights of Artsakh‚Äôs citizens. üìçThe French President Emanuel Macron commended Armenia for its ‚Äúcourage‚Äù in joining the International Criminal Court. üìçCivilNet journalist receives important anti-corruption prize.

entry.title: Duduk: Jivan Gasparyan Jr. on creating a legacy

media:group.media:title: Duduk: Jivan Gasparyan Jr. on creating a legacy
media:group.media:description:
CivilNet met with renowned duduk player, Jivan Gasparyan Jr. at the Armenian Music Society, where he spoke about the soulful nature of the ancient instrument. Visiting Armenia on the occasion of legendary duduk master Jivan Gasparyan Sr.‚Äôs 95-year Jubilee, his grandson talks about the responsibility he felt to carry on a name and an entire musical legacy. In this interview with CivilNet, we explore the emotional depth that it takes to breathe life into the duduk and why this traditional Armenian instrument resonates with so many on a global level.

entry.title: Iran and India push for trade route through Armenia: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Iran and India push for trade route through Armenia: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìçIran and India talked up the importance of Armenia‚Äôs inclusion in a proposed trade route that would significantly reduce the cost of moving freight across the region. üìç2.2 million tourists visited Armenia in the first 11 months of the year, an all-time record. üìçThe head of the United Nations‚Äô atomic agency insisted Armenia‚Äôs sole nuclear power plant meets international safety standards and can continue operating. üìçA key border crossing with Russia has been reopened after hundreds of Armenian trucks were stalled there for several days, raising fears of a potential trade war.
